title: Unauthorised SaaS OAuth Application Integration
scenario: An employee or attacker grants a third-party application access to a corporate SaaS account using OAuth scopes (e.g., read email, access calendar). These applications may exfiltrate data or maintain persistent access without triggering standard alerts.
detection: CASB, SSPM, SaaS Admin Portals, SIEM, Threat Intelligence Feeds.
mitre: T1528 (Steal Access Token), T1550.001 (Application Access Token), T1098.003 (External Account).

steps.detail: Via admin portal (e.g., Azure AD, Google Workspace).
If malicious behaviour or data leakage is confirmed.
Revoke all tokens granted to the app and refresh user sessions.
If impersonation or token theft is suspected.
Require internal approval for all new app integrations.

title: CI/CD Supply Chain Poisoning via Compromised Base Images
scenario: A developer or CI/CD system pulls a malicious or backdoored container base image from public repositories. This tainted image may contain cryptominers or reverse shells affecting production.
detection: CI/CD Logs, Artifact Scanners, CSPM, Image Scanners (Trivy, Grype).
mitre: T1195.002 (Compromise Software Supply Chain), T1204.003 (Malicious File).

steps.detail: Remove access from all pipelines and registries.
Rebuild services using a verified clean base image.
If compromised image had access to env variables/keys.

title: Privilege Escalation via Misconfigured Cloud IAM Roles
scenario: An attacker identifies and exploits misconfigured IAM roles or trust relationships in cloud platforms (AWS, Azure, GCP) to escalate privileges.
detection: CSPM, SIEM, Cloud Logs (CloudTrail, Azure Activity), Identity Analytics.

steps.detail: Invalidate session tokens or access keys.
Remove over-permissive roles and tighten policies.

title: Third-Party Vendor Compromise
scenario: A breach occurs within a vendor's environment that has direct access (VPN, API) to the organisation. Attacker leverages this trust to move laterally.
detection: SIEM, Threat Intel, Vendor Notification, Identity Logs.
mitre: T1195.002 (Compromise Software Supply Chain), T1133 (External Remote Services).

steps.detail: Suspend VPN, API keys, and federated accounts.
If access originated from known malicious infrastructure.
Reset API keys and passwords used by the vendor.

title: API Abuse by Compromised Automation Scripts
scenario: Attacker gains access to API keys embedded in automation scripts or CI/CD files. These secrets are exploited to perform unauthorised actions.
detection: API Gateway Logs, SIEM, WAF, Secret Scanners.
mitre: T1528 (Steal Access Token), T1552.001 (Credentials in Files).

steps.detail: Stop the automation job to prevent reuse.
Purge commits with secrets from Git history.

title: Persistent Access via Cloud Backdoor Accounts
scenario: Attacker creates hidden IAM users or service accounts to maintain persistence after initial compromise.
detection: Cloud Audit Logs, CSPM, Identity Governance.

title: Unauthorised Access via Misconfigured Reverse Proxies
scenario: Attacker exploits misconfigured proxy (Nginx, HAProxy) to bypass auth or access internal APIs.
detection: WAF Logs, Reverse Proxy Logs, SIEM.
mitre: T1133 (External Remote Services), T1190 (Exploit Public-Facing Application)

title: Man-in-the-Middle (MitM) in Hybrid Environments
scenario: Attacker intercepts traffic between endpoints and backend systems via rogue Wi-Fi, DNS spoofing or compromised edge devices.
detection: NDR, EDR, DNS Logs, TLS Fingerprinting.

title: Session Hijacking via Token Replay
scenario: Attacker captures and reuses a valid session token (JWT, OAuth, Cookie) to impersonate a user.
detection: SIEM, CASB, Cloud Logs, Browser Telemetry.
mitre: T1539 (Steal Web Session Cookie), T1550.004 (Token Replay)

title: Lateral Movement via Federated Identity
scenario: Attacker compromises a SaaS account and uses identity federation (SAML/OAuth) to pivot to on-prem resources.
detection: Identity Logs (Okta, Azure AD), VPN Logs, SIEM.

title: Data Exfiltration via Encrypted DNS Tunnels (DoH/DoT)
scenario: Attacker uses DoH or DoT to create a covert channel for C2 or exfiltration, bypassing traditional DNS monitoring.
detection: NDR, JA3 Fingerprinting, DNS Proxy Logs.

title: Business Email Compromise via OAuth App Abuse
scenario: Attacker tricks user into authorising a malicious OAuth app to read/send email, bypassing MFA.
detection: Mail Audit Logs, CASB, Identity Logs.

title: Destructive Malware in Hybrid AD Environments
scenario: Wiper or ransomware impacts both on-prem AD and Cloud AD, targeting Domain Controllers.
detection: EDR, SIEM, DC Logs, Backup Alerts.
mitre: T1485 (Data Destruction), T1486 (Data Encrypted for Impact)

title: Ransomware Targeting Cloud Storage Buckets
scenario: Attacker accesses cloud buckets (S3, Blob) and encrypts or deletes objects using compromised keys.
mitre: T1486 (Data Encrypted for Impact), T1530 (Data from Cloud Storage)

title: Insider Data Theft via Unmanaged Personal Cloud Apps
scenario: Employee uploads sensitive files to personal cloud storage (Drive, Dropbox) via browser or sync client.
mitre: T1567 (Exfiltration Over Web Service), T1041 (Exfiltration C2)

title: Supply Chain Compromise via Third-Party Software Updates
scenario: Trusted vendor is compromised; malicious code is injected into legitimate software updates pushed to endpoints.
detection: EDR, Threat Intel, File Integrity Monitoring.

title: Malware-Laced PDF Uploads to Public Portals
scenario: Attacker uploads PDF with malware (macro/JS) to public portal; staff opens it, triggering compromise.
mitre: T1203 (Exploitation for Client Execution), T1059 (Command Execution)

title: Account Takeover via Legacy Authentication Protocols
scenario: Attacker uses brute force or credential stuffing on legacy protocols (IMAP, POP3, SMTP) to bypass MFA.

title: Data Tampering in Business-Critical Databases
scenario: Privileged insider or attacker modifies/deletes data in critical DBs (ERP, CRM) without authorisation.
detection: DAM (Database Activity Monitoring), SIEM, Audit Logs.

title: DNS-Based C2 from Embedded IoT Devices
scenario: Compromised IoT device uses DNS tunnelling for C2 communication to evade firewall rules.
detection: NDR, DNS Logs, IoT Security Platform.

title: Initial Access via Malicious Browser Extensions
scenario: User installs malicious extension that steals cookies/tokens or redirects traffic.

title: Unauthorised Use of Offensive Security Tools
scenario: Detection of tools like Mimikatz, Cobalt Strike, or BloodHound running in the internal network.

title: Lateral Movement via Shared Cloud Drives
scenario: Attacker uses shared cloud folders (OneDrive/Google Drive) to distribute malware or links internally.
detection: CASB, Cloud Audit Logs, Email Gateway.

title: Compromise via Misconfigured SaaS Integrations
scenario: Attacker exploits unvetted SaaS integrations to access data or bypass MFA.

title: Privilege Escalation via Vulnerable Drivers
scenario: Attacker loads a vulnerable signed driver (BYOVD) to exploit kernel and bypass EDR.

title: Data Exposure via Misconfigured Cloud Storage
scenario: Cloud bucket (S3/Blob) misconfigured to public access, exposing sensitive PII or backups.

title: Insider Abuse of Monitoring or Admin Tools
scenario: Admin misuses legitimate tools (Splunk, SCCM) to view sensitive data or disable logging.

title: Backdoor Persistence via Rogue Browser Update
scenario: User tricked into installing fake browser update which installs a backdoor or RAT.

title: Token Theft via Cross-Site Scripting (XSS)
scenario: Attacker exploits XSS to steal session cookies or OAuth tokens from users.

title: Remote Desktop Exposure via Misconfigured Firewall/NAT
scenario: RDP/SSH exposed to internet via firewall misconfiguration, leading to brute force attacks.

title: Business Email Compromise via OAuth Token Abuse
scenario: Variant of PB-12: Attacker uses stolen token to access mailbox without credential theft.
detection: Identity Logs, CASB, Mail Audit Logs.

title: Data Exfiltration via DNS Tunnelling
scenario: Data exfiltration via encoded DNS queries (long subdomains) to attacker-controlled resolver.

title: Compromise Through Vulnerable Open-Source Components
scenario: Exploitation of known vulnerabilities (e.g., Log4j) in web apps to execute code.

title: Command and Control via Cloud Storage Platforms
scenario: Malware uses Dropbox/Drive for C2 instructions to blend with normal traffic.

title: Persistence Through Malicious Browser Extensions
scenario: Malicious extension installed to maintain access and steal data over time.

title: Ransomware via Third-Party Vendor Compromise
scenario: MSP or vendor compromised, leading to ransomware deployment via trusted RMM/VPN.

title: Secrets Leakage Through Public Git Repositories
scenario: Developer commits API keys/secrets to public Git, leading to cloud compromise.

title: Privilege Escalation via Unpatched Endpoint Software
scenario: Attacker exploits unpatched local vulnerability (LPE) to gain System privileges.

title: Lateral Movement via Service Account Abuse
scenario: Compromised service account credentials used to move laterally across servers.

title: Initial Access via Phishing with Malicious Macros
scenario: Phishing email with macro-enabled attachment executes malware (e.g., Emotet).

title: Cloud Credential Theft from Exposed Config Files
scenario: Cloud keys left in exposed config files on web servers or shares.

title: Data Exfiltration via Misconfigured S3 Buckets
scenario: S3 bucket set to public allows attacker to download massive datasets.

title: Unauthorised VPN Access from Reused Credentials
scenario: Attacker uses valid credentials (from breach/reuse) to login to VPN.

title: Initial Access via Rogue IoT Devices
scenario: Rogue IoT device connected to physical network to scan and attack internally.

title: Unauthorised Cloud Admin Role Escalation
scenario: Attacker exploits IAM policies to assume high-privilege Admin roles.

title: Data Exfiltration via Cloud Sync Abuse
scenario: Insider syncs corporate data to personal cloud (OneDrive/Dropbox) via client.

title: Initial Access via OAuth Token Abuse (Browser Session Hijacking)
scenario: Attacker steals browser session cookie to bypass MFA and access OAuth apps.

title: Persistence via Cloud Workload Implants
scenario: Attacker implants malicious code into Serverless functions (Lambda/Azure Functions).
detection: Cloud Logs, CSPM, Source Code Logs.

title: Command-and-Control via Trusted Third-Party APIs
scenario: Attacker uses Slack/Telegram/Google Sheets APIs for C2 traffic.

title: Privilege Escalation Through SaaS Misconfigurations
scenario: Exploiting SaaS settings (e.g., delegated admin) to gain unauthorised privileges.
